sentences.sentence: Responses to Opinion articles by Nicholas Kristof and Michelle Cottle.

Also: A voice for unions; Ukraine's fate; promoting diversity on campus.To the Editor:Re “How We Can Fix Our Loneliness Epidemic,” by Nicholas Kristof (column, Sept. 7), and “Flexible Housing,” by Michelle Cottle (Opinion, Sept. 10):In recent weeks, Mr. Kristof and Ms. Cottle have written convincingly about the problems of loneliness and isolation and the need for more flexible housing options as our population ages.

In neither piece was there any mention of the option of home sharing, which is a low-cost and immediate means of aiding the housing crisis for both young and old.AtHome Share Oregon,a nonprofit based in Portland, we connect homeowners who have spare rooms ᅳ many of whom are mortgage-burdened, lonely and living on meager Social Security checks ᅳ with renters struggling to find a home.While our mission is to help alleviate the affordable housing crisis by utilizing a large untapped inventory and preventing homelessness before it starts for both owners and renters, our program also assists those who are lonely and isolated and who benefit from the social interaction that comes with home sharing.There was a time when boardinghouses were part of the cultural norm and helped bring people together.
Over time that became stigmatized.

We are working to change the cultural norm by moving forward with a proven means of housing people while at the same time building financial resilience and combating the loneliness epidemic.Stan PenkinPortland, Ore.To the Editor:Some more ideas for addressing loneliness that have been working on my block of suburbia: a free little library of children's books in front of my house; firing the gardener and doing my own gardening in front of my house; walking the dog and meeting all the other dog walkers; passing out Christmas cookies; trading plants.I don't have a porch with a swinging bench, but I do sit with my coffee on a built-in planter and read the paper and greet people who walk by.

All you have to do is try.Jane WardenMalibu, Calif.To the Editor:“How We Can Fix Our Loneliness Epidemic” is marred by the claim, “Meanwhile, time with screens substitutes for time with human beings.” This view, which exemplifies the anti-internet bias pervading current discussions of loneliness, overlooks the fact that time spent on screens is often time with human beings.The internet enables me to interact with a much more diverse range of people than I can meet in my local community and to ward off loneliness by forming deep friendships that are based on mutual interests and emotional compatibility rather than mere propinquity.Felicia Nimue AckermanProvidence, R.I.A Voice for Unions: President BidenTo the Editor:Re “President Strongly Defends Striking Autoworkers” (front page, Sept. 16):President Biden is right: Automakers “should go further to ensure record corporate profits mean record contracts for the U.A.W.”That's why the U.A.W.
began a limited strike against General Motors, Ford and Stellantis.
This is all about accountability, respect and the future of electric vehicles.It's hardly a surprise that company executives don't understand the union.
They're not alone.
Most C.E.O.s today came of age after Ronald Reagan was elected.
They've never known a world where unions were treated with respect and corporate accountability.

In fact, President Reagan set the example when hefired the air traffic controllers and broke their union.The dirty little secret, though, is that until President Biden, Democrats shared the blame for ignoring labor unions.

After the shock of Mr. Reagan's election, Democrats, desperate for money and business support, created the Democratic Business Council, inviting C.E.O.s for exclusive sessions with members of Congress.

When labor unions asked to join the council, they were told, “No.”Now, for the first time in decades, labor unions have a strong voice in Washington: President Joe Biden.Robert E. McGarrah Jr.Bethesda, Md.The writer, an attorney with Maryland Legal Aid, was counsel to the A.F.L.-C.I.O.

Office of Investment.Ukraine's Fate, and the World'sTo the Editor:Re “I Saw Firsthand How Much Is at Stake in Ukraine,” by Thomas L. Friedman, and “Can Samantha Power Change Ukraine's Future?,” by Bret Stephens (columns, Sept. 17):Mr. Friedman and Mr. Stephens outdid themselves with their heartfelt and insightful firsthand accounts of the importance of events in Ukraine.
I read them both twice.It's truly inspiring that Ukrainians have united so courageously in the face of imperialist aggression that the civilized world had assumed was a disgraceful relic of history.

The United States and Europe must help them win that fight.American politics may present its frustrations, but what is happening in Ukraine is something of an entirely different level of importance to the world.There are so many reasons that a second Trump presidency would be disastrous for America.
But tragically, a return to power for Donald Trump, with his affinity for Vladimir Putin, would delay the eventual inevitable triumph of individual freedom over state-imposed tyranny for years.

The future of human history is in the balance.George HicksNashvilleA 'Misguided' Effort to Promote Diversity at CollegesTo the Editor:Re “Diversity Statements by Faculty Complicate Hiring on Campus” (front page, Sept. 10):In 1950, the California state university system required all employees to sign an anti-Communistloyalty oath, which resulted in the firing of professors unwilling to sign.
More than 70 years later, the very same institutions requirean acceptably worded D.E.I.

statementas a condition to hiring.While today's goals may be laudable, an ideological litmus test of any kind is both misguided and an unconstitutional infringement on free speech.Daniel WolfTeaneck, N.J.To the Editor:This article prompts the hypothetical question whether a latter-day Albert Einstein would have a chance of employment at Berkeley or a number of other University of California campuses.When asked about his commitment to diversity, that world-class physicist would likely give a response along the lines of these words he once said: “I speak to everyone in the same way, whether he is the garbage man or the president of the university.”That fails, on Berkeley's scoring rubric, to indicate sufficient alignment with the ideology the college expects all faculty to share.
And that would be the end of the applicant's candidacy in almost every instance.U.C.
's research universities have been home to many of America's greatest scientists and scholars.

Now several of them privilege activism when recruiting new faculty and otherwise do not even bother to consider the research and teaching records of applicants.Research universities are the engines of scientific and technological progress, but U.C.

has instead embraced dysfunctional ideological conformity.Michael B. PoliakoffWashingtonThe writer is the president of the American Council of Trustees and Alumni.This article appeared in print on page A27.
